text: Whew, so many people go way too deep into this. If you want the highlights, they need to understand how content ranks (search intent) and understand how links work in SEO (and what content to create to get more of them). That's literally it. They're already content pros so no need for them to dive into all the tiny stuff that barely moves the needle.

elements.text: Whew, so many people go way too deep into this. If you want the highlights, they need to understand how content ranks (search intent) and understand how links work in SEO (and what content to create to get more of them). That's literally it. They're already content pros so no need for them to dive into all the tiny stuff that barely moves the needle.

text: Does anyone have any evidence that adding "categories" (ie, how Acquire has this <https://acquire.io/blog/category/customer-support/|customer support category>) that people can click into on a blog has any impact on pages per session / bounce rate, etc? we're doing a blog redesign and we don't currently have that, and it makes me wonder if it's something that we should add in or if it's just one of those things that's "always done" but doesn't actually do anything

text: I don’t have any data on adding them in as we’ve aways had category pages but i can tell you that about 5% of the pageviews on our content page end up using a category filter to narow content.

text:
I also don’t have the data (left the company). But will be doing this at my new gig because it works. 

The thing is, simply adding those categories won’t magically improve reader/user retention. You need to show readers/users that those things have meaning. Visual UI elements on the blog homepage and within posts that say “read more about this category or collection” are needed. 

Dropbox and Intercom are great examples of this.

elements.text: I also don’t have the data (left the company). But will be doing this at my new gig because it works.

The thing is, simply adding those categories won’t magically improve reader/user retention. You need to show readers/users that those things have meaning. Visual UI elements on the blog homepage and within posts that say “read more about this category or collection” are needed.
Dropbox and Intercom are great examples of this.

text:
Hello everyone,

I've heard over and over to write for one person or have one real person in mind and talk to her/him when creating a price of content. 
I think this approach makes the writing process easier and faster but I'm not sure how it will work out. I mean wouldn't it make the content too much personal or specific? Do you have any experience with this? I hope my explanation makes sense and isn't too vague!

elements.text:
Hello everyone,

I've heard over and over to write for one person or have one real person in mind and talk to her/him when creating a price of content. 
I think this approach makes the writing process easier and faster but I'm not sure how it will work out. I mean wouldn't it make the content too much personal or specific? Do you have any experience with this? I hope my explanation makes sense and isn't too vague!

text:
I think it's more about speaking to your audience's specific situation. Not, "I'm talking to Bob in accounting" but "I'm speaking to people in this specific accounting role who are experiencing this specific challenge."

In other words: speak to their situation, not their disposition.

elements.text:
I think it's more about speaking to your audience's specific situation. Not, "I'm talking to Bob in accounting" but "I'm speaking to people in this specific accounting role who are experiencing this specific challenge."

In other words: speak to their situation, not their disposition.

text: Yeah, that makes sense. I have actually seen one issue in marketing department of couple of companies and I'm trying to address that. So, I find talking to one of them in my mind and writing it down makes it easier to create a peice.

elements.text: Yeah, that makes sense. I have actually seen one issue in marketing department of couple of companies and I'm trying to address that. So, I find talking to one of them in my mind and writing it down makes it easier to create a peice.

text:
I'm fully in "write for one person only camp" :slightly_smiling_face:

I have edited hundreds of articles from people at all stages of their career and this is consistently the advice that results in the best first draft. t is an incredibly useful shortcut to make your content relevant, specific, and meaningful. It has some other benefits too:
1. It's a better mistake --> Erring on the side of being too personal and potential excluding readers consistently results in better writing than erring on the side of being too general. (The latter is _boring)_
2. It's easier to edit --> Making a too-personal piece more generally applicable is an easy 20-minute edit. Making a too-general piece more specific is a headache.

When I've done persona exercises I also use real people and have found that to the be the only effective way to help people really wrap their head around a persona.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

It's a better mistake --> Erring on the side of being too personal and potential excluding readers consistently results in better writing than erring on the side of being too general. (The latter is
boring)
It's easier to edit --> Making a too-personal piece more generally applicable is an easy 20-minute edit. Making a too-general piece more specific is a headache.
When I've done persona exercises I also use real people and have found that to the be the only effective way to help people really wrap their head around a persona.

text: Thanks Janessa! It's really great to hear that I'm on the right track :)

elements.text: Thanks Janessa! It's really great to hear that I'm on the right track :)

text: Also anecdotal (from Intercom days) but I agree with above, categories are just a better reader experience–imagine going to a bookstore without categories! That category header is also a quick n easy reflection of the breadth of your product, eg. a salesperson might not realize that you offer solutions/content for engineers too.
